goal.ch: In modern terms, this course should be named Condensed Matter Physics I. It aims to equip graduate students (or senior undergraduates) with an in-depth understanding of the properties and behaviors of crystalline solids through the use of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics.
goal.en: In modern terms, this course should be named Condensed Matter Physics I. It aims to equip graduate students (or senior undergraduates) with an in-depth understanding of the properties and behaviors of crystalline solids through the use of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics.

outline.ch:
Lattice and symmetry, crystal structure and scattering, dynamics of lattice vibration, quantum theory of harmonic crystal, electronic structure, semiclassical transport theory, quantum magnetism.
If time permits: topological phases, interacting electrons, superconductivity.
Prerequisites: graduate quantum mechanics I (which can be taken concurrently); familiarity with graduate statistical mechanics I is preferred but not required; knowledge of undergraduate solid state physics is helpful but not necessary.

textbook.ch:
Main textbook: One of the books listed as references 1 to 7 in the following will be assigned later.

Useful graduate-level references:

1. Solid State Physics, N. W. Ashcroft and N. D. Mermin, Cengage Learning (1976).

2. Fundamentals of Condensed Matter Physics, M. L. Cohen and S. G. Louie, Cambridge University Express (2016). 

3. Quantum Theory of Materials, E. Kaxiras and J. D. Joannopoulos, Cambridge University Express (2019). 

4. Modern Condensed Matter Physics, S. M. Girvin and K. Yang, Cambridge University Express (2019). 

5. Solid-State Physics: An Introduction to Principles of Materials Science, H. Ibach and H. Lüth, Springer (2009) [eBook ISBN: 9783540938040].

6. Solid State Physics, G. Grosso and G. P. Parravicini, Academic Press (2013).

7. Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics: Volume 1, D. Feng and G. Jin, World Scientific (2005).

8. Advanced Quantum Condensed Matter Physics: One-Body, Many-Body, and Topological Perspectives, M. El-Batanouny, Cambridge University Express (2020). 

9. Fundamentals of the Physics of Solids, Volume 2: Electronic Properties, J. Solyom, Springer (2009) [eBook ISBN: 9783540726005].

Useful undergraduate-level references:

10. The Oxford Solid State Basics, S. H. Simon, Oxford University Press (2013) [see also the online lectures recording at Oxford: https://podcasts.ox.ac.uk/series/oxford-solid-state-basics]. 

11. Kittel‘s Introduction to Solid State Physics, C. Kittel, Wiley (2018).

12. Lectures on Solid State Physics, D. Tong, http://www.damtp.cam.ac.uk/user/tong/solidstate.html

gradMethod.ch:
Scheme 1: homework 60％, written report or oral exam 40％.

Scheme 2: homework 50％, written report or oral exam 40％, performance 10％.

Final grade = max(Scheme 1, Scheme 2).
